summary: This document is an email chain from November 2008 among U.S. Attorney's Office personnel discussing a draft response to a letter from an attorney named Edwards regarding the Jeffrey Epstein case. The emails debate the tone and content of the response, with one participant suggesting a minimal reply that reiterates the office's role in the criminal investigation and invites submission of evidence related to the Non-Prosecution Agreement.

persons.name: Edwards
persons.context: An attorney who sent a letter on October 15, 2008, to the U.S. Attorney's Office regarding the Jeffrey Epstein case, prompting the internal discussion about a response.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: Referred to as 'Mr. Epstein,' the subject of the criminal investigation and related civil suits. The Non-Prosecution Agreement involving him is central to the correspondence.

persons.name: AUS
persons.context: An Assistant U.S. Attorney to whom evidence of a breach of the Non-Prosecution Agreement could be forwarded, as suggested in a draft response.

connections.description: Edwards appears to be corresponding with the U.S. Attorney's Office about Epstein, likely in a legal capacity, possibly as an attorney for a party in a civil suit or as a concerned party regarding the Non-Prosecution Agreement.
The AUS is part of the office conducting the criminal investigation of Epstein and would be responsible for reviewing evidence related to the Non-Prosecution Agreement.

events.title: Edwards' Letter to U.S. Attorney's Office
events.description: Attorney Edwards sent a letter to the U.S. Attorney's Office, the contents of which prompted an internal discussion about crafting a response.

events.title: Internal Email Discussion on Draft Response
events.description: U.S. Attorney's Office personnel exchanged emails debating the content and strategy for responding to Edwards' October 15, 2008, letter concerning Jeffrey Epstein and the Non-Prosecution Agreement.

keyFacts: The U.S. Attorney's Office was actively involved in the criminal investigation of Jeffrey Epstein as of November 2008.
A Non-Prosecution Agreement involving Jeffrey Epstein existed and was a subject of legal correspondence and potential review.
Internal emails reveal strategic caution among prosecutors about writing letters that could be made public or used in pleadings.
The correspondence indicates external legal scrutiny (from attorney Edwards) regarding the Epstein investigation and the Non-Prosecution Agreement.
